column2: Black Crag, or Karak Drazh in Khazalid, is the largest and most well known Greenskin stronghold in the world. When the Dwarfs still held the Black Crag, it provided a strong defensable position in the south of the Worlds Edge mountains, and was also a very rich hold. It would survive the Time of Woes, but would fall shortly after to Greenskins, turning the once great hold into a scar on the Dwarfs honor and history.

Khypris, the city of splendours, is a massive trade city located in the borderlands, once the capital of the grand Khyprote empire in ages past. While the empire is long gone from most human minds, the prestige and power of the city remained, and as such is considered the greatest city between Myrmidens and Akendorf.

Akendorf, once the captial of a long lost Imperial borderlands Elector-County, is the center of all Imperial influence in the borderlands, straddeling the boundry of what the Imperials consider the 'civilized' world, it is a city that is constantly under threat. Not just from the Orks of the badlands, or Goblins from the mountains, but from the inummerable Beastman tribes that inhabit the foreboding Stygian Woods. Due to this, Akendorf is considered the weakest between Khypris and Myrmidens.

Myrmidens is the second largest city-state in the Borderlands, capital of the Aegean Principality, one of the sucessor states of the Myrmidan Empire. The days of Myrmidia's Empire are long gone, but the proud and civic traditions it left behind are still strong, reflected in Myrmidens' strong, yet elegant walls, designed to impress and intimidate would-be conquerors and foreign diplomats. Dealings with Dwarf holds have increased Myrmidens' importance not only as a trading hub, but also as a technological and military center, as both Human and Dwarf work closely with each other to stamp out the Greenskin threat to the south.

Al-Haikk is traditionally the capital of Araby, whenever the nation is united. Once known as the “Jewel of Araby”, the city has declined importance in recent years, with continued wars, disasters and sieges targeting it due its source of legitimacy as the seat of the Great Sultan of All-Araby. While it’s usually called the “City of Thieves” nowadays, due to the rampant depopulation – and thievery – in some of its old quarters, and overshadowed by other thriving rival cities, it remains a prestigious location to all Arabyans.

The Arabyan Ksar, or "citadel" in the Imperial tongue, is the central administration complex for all Arabyan military settlements. While the Ksar is the military might of the Arabyans, their architecture is legendary, full of impossible shapes, domed-roof buildings, and a myriad of spires, all linked with small walkways to get to-and-from. This not only serves to appease foreign emissaries, but to provide a confusing, maze-like structure, making it difficult for invaders to successfully take an Arabyan settlement.

The Tarikah are lightly armored sword-and-bow infantry units that act as the mainstay for any Arabyan army. While Araby fields the finest cavalry in the Human world, their infantry are nothing to scoff at, as the art of sword dancing and the skills of their bowmen are impressive.

The Shushtar used to be an ancient Arabyan tribe that used mounted archery and lightning fast cavalry strikes to great effect against the old Nehekharan empire. While their tribe would eventually perish, their fighting style would not, and the Nomadic Nehekkas, Tevari, and the Urban Ramaccans now use it to once again wreak havoc onto their foes.

The Shariati are the 'heavy' cavalry components of Cophic and nomadic Arabyan armies. Unlike the Shushtar, who use mounted archery and harass tactics, the Shariati make use of the sturdy Arabyan camel to deliver devastating charges unto enemy lines. It is also known that foreign horses(those that are not native to Araby) are afraid of camels due to their smell, and so the camel cavalry was also initially the reason for many Arabyan victories during the crusades.

The Ramaccan Janissary is the penultimate, modern Arabyan warrior. Raised from a young age to be a killing machine, these soldiers are of the highest quality an Arabyan lord can field, and normally serve as his or her bodyguards and elite detachments in the field of battle. Heavily armed, incredibly disciplined, these warriors make short work of anyone foolish enough to stand in their path.

The Cataphract is an old Cophic idea made new. Much like the Ramaccan Jannisary, the Cophic Cataphract is an elite warrior of mostly noble stock, given the finest weapons, armor, steeds, and training to create a terrifying mounted warrior capable of smashing through enemy lines with frightening speed and grace.

Due to the many colonies established by the Medeans in the Southlands, their various city-states can field the impressive Southland Elephants, gigantic beasts of war from deep within the jungles of the south. These elephants are accompanied by Southland tribesmen, who paint various symbols and images onto their elephants to intimidate and frighten their enemies.

In the harsh deserts and sand dunes of Araby and Nehekhara, heavy armour and infantry are mostly impractical. Due to this, and the nature of the lifestyle of the Tevari and Nehekkas, most of their number fight on horseback. Lightly armored, these warriors are quick enough to chase down even mounted skirmishers.

Found almost everywhere in Araby, the caravansary is the lifeblood of trade. It functions much like a marketplace from foreign lands, but larger, and full of exotic foods, crafts, people and creatures.
Here is where the fabled corsairs of Araby make port. Home to some of the most feared men in the oceans, easily capable of chasing down vulnerable trade ships and other soft targets in their dhows.

While most soldiers raised in Arabyan cities are militia units, one should not mistake these riders as amateur or of poor quality. Horsemanship is a very serious and respected skill in Araby, and those cavalry units raised here are of no lesser quality than those trained in the Ksars.

While many would say that the towering spires of the Ksars, or the daemonic, spell-bounded Djinn are what Araby is most known for, it is instead their cities' great bazaars, magnificent sections of Arabyan cities, mostly open air, full of exotic goods, everyday supplies, and of course, many stalls full of crafts and goods of questionable quality and authenticity.

Arabyans are know for two things, their horsemen, and their caravans. Here, in the beautiful cities that hug the deserts or sea-sides, the vast majority of caravans end up at. Much like the Ksars, the architecture of an Arabyan city makes it very difficult to siege properly.

Here is where an Arabyan city's foot-bound militia units are trained and housed. Armed with bows, spears, and swords, these militia units can hold their own in the field of battle, and can also reliably police Arabyan cities.

Due to the closeness of the Southlands and Araby, -not just geographically speaking- most, if not all Arabyan cities have city quarters inhabited by Southlanders. While this may seem innocent at first, these quarters more often than not are poorly maintained, and lawless, save for one part, the War-Elephant pens. Great care is taken in maintaining these pens, for should an Elephant get lose in a city, it could be disastrous.

The Grand Library is the center of most Arabyan scholarship, be it scientific or religious in nature. Here, one can find a vast array of books written by scientists, philosophers, mathematicians, and even theologians in the great halls of the library, as well as a secret vault designed to house the Djinni, spell-bound daemons used by scholars as guards, or in times of war, soldiers.

The Burning Scimitars are an elite fighting forces stationed inside the Arabyan Grand Libraries. They are mostly composed of veterans of previous wars, thus making them stubborn defenders should the library come under attack, or if the scholars lose control of their Djinni.

Just outside the library, in a separate building live the stallions ridden into battle by the Burning Scimitars' mounted counterparts. Due to the power the libraries hold over Araby, they are given the best equipment and training, even if they are not the sons of a rich merchant or noble.

The library is not all study and work, for fine art faculties also set up inside the building. While most of their work is for the people of Araby, a fraction of their crafts are actually vessels used by the scholars to spell-bind daemons to objects, so that they may be controlled and used against the enemies of Araby.

While the local lord and surrounding province may not follow the teachings of Ormazd, many scholars that live inside the library do, with this section devoted entirely to the school of Ahgrimanite thought, which preaches that Ormazd was a patron of reason and free thought.

While the local lord and surrounding province may not follow the teachings of Ormazd, many scholars that live inside the library do, with this section devoted entirely to the school of Zirvite thought, which preaches that Ormazd was a patron of tradition and faith.

The school of Geosis, or Geosite thought, is a relatively new school of thought, brought along by Tileans and Bretonnians from the crusades. It preaches that Ormazd valued the material world above all else, and that only through absolute obedience would Araby prevail.

Inside a vault deep within the library dwell the Djinni, bounded daemons used by Arabyan scholars for a multitude of tasks, chores, and research possibilities. While they are normally kept lock up inside the vault for their own safety, in times of war the scholars will call upon them to aid Arabyan armies in battle, providing shock troops and other types of supporting units.

Magritta is the largest and probably the most important settlement in Estalia. Located on the southern shore of the peninsula, it’s one of the main trading ports of the Southern Seas. Magritta maintains a strong maritime presence here, and aggressively patrols its waters against Sartosan pirates, Arabyan corsairs and, while at it, imposes a “toll” on foreign ships moving through its territory. It is also the home of the Archecclesiatium, the main temple of the Cult of Myrmidia.

Bilbali is, in many ways, a stark contrast to its southern rival, Magritta. Where Margitta’s climate is warm and bright, Bilbali is always covered in rain and fog. While Magritta’s golden shores are bathed by the temperate waters of the Southern Seas, the waves of the Great Ocean clash against the rocky cliffs of Bilbali. This is noticeable even their produce, as Bilbali’s main export is the weaponry in their military arsenals and gunpowder refineries. It also acts as a trading hub between Lustria and the Old World, and the city is unusually welcoming of Bretonnian merchants ( For an Estalian city, that is ).

One of the mightiest city-states of Tilea, Miragliano is always assailed by the plagues and insidious ratmen coming from the Blighted Marshes to its west. As a result, the city itself is highly fortified, with walls specially designed to give maximum advantage to artillery firing from it, and towers that never crumble even when leaning at near-comical angles. These excellently planned fortifications are the results of the sponsorship of engineering, science and other arts by the Princes of Miragliano. Thus, it is not surprise that this was the city to give birth to the genius inventor and engineer, Leonardo da Miragliano.

Remas is the greatest and most ancient city in Tilea. It is home to a huge circular port, said to have been built when the city was still a High Elf trading post, and even in the ruined and dilapidated state it is now, it still houses the powerful Reman fleet. A great bridge links the city proper to the port, and also houses many businesses and the fine palaces of the merchant princes. Remas proper is laid out on a grand scale within a long circuit of defenses, and protected by mercenary companies of pikemen that fight in the ancient style.

Here are where the sellswords reside, lightly armored swordsmen, usually made up of deserters from foreign lands, impetuous duelists and other scoundrels, usually hired to protect the flanks of Pike and Crossbow regiments.

Tilean Pike and Crossbow regiments are trained here. Each regiment has a long history, and many record their services as as mercenaries as well as professional soldiery with pride. The Tilean Princes will usually employ these kind of companies as the mainstay of their personal armies.

Tilea is a mountainous and hilly region, unbefitting of horse warfare, so most Princes don't train or equip any kind of horsemen in their personal armies. Instead, they employ Freelancers, made up from robber knights and disgraced nobles, usually from Bretonnia, the Empire or Kislev. They make up a strong heavy cavalry formation, most of the time.

Ogres are known to sell themselves are mercenaries for payment, adventure, and above all, food, meaning they are very easy to maintain. A camp of Ogres has been established in this province, allowing the ruler to raise heavy shock troops in times of war. These Ogres however, are not very fond of cannons.

Tilea's terrain does not allow for larger cannons that the Dwarf and Imperial armies field, so much more emphasis is put on mobility rather than caliber. This does not make them any less deadly, or any less louder for that matter.

The main keeps of Tilean fortresses are usually ostentatious palaces built by its myriad of Princes. While they lack the typical garrison of armoured footmen and free riders of other realms, they make up with a veritable army of philosophers, painters, sculptors and other polymaths seeking patronage, who make the abodes of Tliean princes into true cultural – and financial - centers.

The Castellumos, or 'Castle' in Myken, is the military center for the region, housing most of a Myken lord's levies and retinues, as well as some servants. Due to the increasing in Tilean pressure on the Mykens, many Castellumoi employ large amounts of artisans or philosophers, adopting and melding the Tilean and Myken arts together into a fascinating blend.

The Akritai are the main skirmishing force for the Myken armies, equipped with javelins, crossbows, and sometimes even long bows. Like most Myken soldiery, these troops are professional soldiers, with paid saleries and terms for service, most signing a 5 year term, with the chance of either retiring after or continuing service and being promoted to a more prestigious rank. Akritai however, are much more loose in this regard, and many are Game wardens or hunters during times of peace, giving them an edge in the dark woods of Stygia or in the scorching heat of the badlands.

The Comitos, or Comitoi, are the heavy standing infantry force of the Mykens, and are second in prestige only to the Excubitoroi. Like the Akritai and Excubitoroi, they have paid saleries and terms for service, but unlike the Akritai, it is not uncommon for Comitoi to be rewared small plots of land in return for their services in war, in addition to their saleries, making them stubborn defenders that do not retreat easily.

The Excubitoroi guard are the finest horsemen in the borderlands and badlands, only surpassed by the Arabyans in the south in horsemanship, of which the Excubitoroi learn much from. These guards are the highest in the Myken tier system, and many are either minor nobles or wealthy merchant sons looking for honor and glory, or, in the case of the captains of the guard, the lord or lady's ear. Heavily armoured, incredibly disciplined, these riders make quick work of any Orkish or Beastman horde that dares to encroach upon a Myken's land.

The Limetatoi, or 'garrison', are those that guard the Limes of a Myken lord or lady's border, and are normally a citizen's first line of defense against any invading threat. Not terribly armoured, nor incredibly disciplined, the Limetatoi's job is to just hold the line until the Comitoi and Excubitoroi arrive to clean up the invaders.

Myken Scutarii are the only militia units in a Myken army, being composed entirely of spears, and in some cases pikes, Scutarii are only raised in cities, and are most similar to the Bretonnian peasant levies in terms of quality and equipment. While they would most certainly lose in a one on one fight, the Scutarii's job is mostly for holding ground and stopping cavalry, something their spears and pikes allow them to do very well.

The Ballistarii are crossbow wielding heavy skirmisher troops designed to kill other skirmisher and heavy infantry formations with their powerful siege crossbows. Due to the close relationship between the Mykens and the Dwarves, the Ballistarii's crossbows are of superior make compared to the Estalian or Tilean models, easily puncturing plate mail and in some cases being forceful enough to pass through multiple targets.

The Atamoi are the wealthy sons of merchants or ruler republican leaders, pressed into service so that the merchantile class may receive more recognition for their services to their lord or lady. They are not as heavily armoured or disciplined as the Excubitoroi, but make good units for harassing armies and chasing down fleeing enemies.

A Myken city is an intriqueing sight to behold for any traveller visitng the Borderlands. In stark contrast between the grim outlook of many minor villages and forts in the area, Myken cities are centers of trade, science, and philosophy, attracting many to their centers and increasing the power that each city wields, many of which could be rivalling city states, if not for the constant Ork or Beastman threat. Due to the increased cultural pressures from Tilea, many Myken cities are adopting and melding the modern look of a Tilean city with the ancient splendours of the old Myken cities.

The Grand Academia is the philosophical and intellectual center of all Myken cities, housing hundreds of scholars, scientists, and philosophers. Many nobles and merchants send their sons to these establishments, some of which even form cults around headmasters of the Academia, most revolving around equations or philosophical terms.
A pirate ship dock, hidden in a rocky cove or wave-tossed inlet. Full of taverns with wenches, rum, and brawling, it houses pirates for when they aren't plundering the high seas.

Most Sartosan Pirates do not both with constructing significant fortifications near their strongholds and cities, instead relying upon the terrain surrounding them or their outlandish positions to protect them from invaders.

The Pirate stronghold is the epicenter of all pirate activity in the region. Outfitted with a tavern and brothel, much of a Pirate Lord or Lady's crew resides here, merry-making until their next outing for plunder.

At the most basic level of Pirate society stand the crew, or scum as they are called unaffectionately by some. Equipped with whatever weapons they can find, honestly or not, and lightly armored, these men are more accustomed to conquering the local wench than an actual army, but can come through in a pinch.

Buccaneers are the Sartosan-Tilean equivalent of lower nobility, having made names for themselves on the high seas, and having access not only to better weapons and armor, but also to the Pirate Lord or Lady's ear. Thus their presence inspires nearby pirates to fight boldly so that they too might become Buccaneers.

Most pirate combatants will fight on foot, as horses are difficult to keep on ships and are a rare privilege for most lords and ladies armies. Those that do field these cavalry units often find that they make great land raiders, easily striking at villages and vanishing before the local forces can organize against the raid.

While the Sartosan-Tileans and Sartosan-Norscans do not field large amounts of cavalry, nor having a standing tradition for horseback fighting, the Arabyans field some of the finest cavalry units the world has seen. The Pirate forces of the Sartosan-Arabyans utilize this knowledge to field larger amounts of cavalry, making them more deadly in combat against foes and victims.

The legendary Corsairs of Araby are well known to all those that sail in the Southern Seas. Preying upon merchant ships in their fast, sleek Dhows, most cannot react in time to fight against the Corsairs. On land, they are just as deadly, wielding dual scimitars, they are masters in the dance of death.

The Muetad are elite Corsair cavalry units, superbly equipped with fine armors, weapons, and Arabyan stallions, these land raiders make short work of armies and can quickly raid entire countrysides in days, leaving little left behind, save for ruin and death.

The Sartosan-Norscan Reaver is a heavily armored berserker, able to cleave through enemy formations with ease, these units allow for Sartosan-Norscan realms to punch well above their weight and stand their ground against retaliatory attackers.

Sartosan Taverns are no so different from any other tavern, except these taverns are much, much more larger than most other Old World taverns, and any respectable building will have ample rum and wenches for the crew when they are not out searching for booty.

The lifeblood of any pirate base, the shipyard houses all of a region's ships in it's well secured ports, heavily guarded by the portwatchers so that any landlubber doesn't come destroying the fleet. Due to the assimilation of various cultures, Sartosans are equalled in ship product to the Norscans, allowing them to raid uncontested pretty much anywhere in the world.

Sartosan-Norscan sharpshooters are elite hunters that have either won, looted, or stolen handguns from various sources, and have been promoted to hunting the greatest game, enemy officers. Crack shots, if somewhat undisciplined, these sharpshooters will make short work of any force foolish enough to stand in one spot for too long.

THe Sartosan-Tilean "stormcannons" are actually pedreros and culverin that have been stolen from Tilean armories to be used for their new pirate masters instead. They have been renamed to "stormcannons" in an effort to appease Stormfels, the fickle god of the seas and patron to all pirates.

Pirate legends tell of many captains that have died and come back from the dead, normally those that were well feared in life, returning as hateful wraiths in death. As fate would have it, these legends are true, and certain vampire lords or ladies may call upon these wraiths to serve in their armies.

While the common image of a pirate is a swash-buckling pillager living on the high seas, many Sartosans, when not doing this, gather together into communities near spots well suited for pirate activities, such as coves or skull islands near the sea side. A good many of these pirate cities exist, most famous being Sartosa itself.

The Zanzibaar is the product of Arabyan and Tilean influences within the Sartosans, constituting a large part of any pirate city, these open air markets are home to many, many stalls selling various goods, common and exotic, from foodstuffs to slaves, and even some 'artifacts'. Though, due to the nature of Sartosan cities, these markets are not as prosperous as their Imperial, Tilean, or Asur counterparts, as Sartosan society revolves around the sea and pillaging others to sate their needs.

The Sartosan port may sound like a separate part of the city, but in actuality it is part of the dockyard of the city, the main economic side of it, or what passes for economics, at least. Bribery and racketeering run rampant here, and much of the income disappears before it even lands, but particularly strong lords or ladies can gain something from the port officials.
Sartosan-Norscan "frostfire" cannons are actually pedreros and culverins that have been stolen from Tilean and Imperial armories to be used for their new pirate masters instead.

In Bretonnia, it is considered below the nobility to practice archery, so this duty is thrust upon the peasantry to provide ranged support for their lieges. Wielding longbows and daggers, they are easily able to out-range most short bowed archers, and deliver enough force from their arrows to piece plate mail.
Men-at-Arms are a Bretonnian noblemen's main foot soldiery, lightly armored, and armed with spears and swords, they are just a step above mere peasant rabble.

Here are where Bretonnia's fabled knights are gathered. The mainstay of any Bretonnian host, the Knights of the Realm can deliver crushing charges that smash through even the heaviest of pike formations.

Here is where the pinnacle of Bretonnia's knightly society gather. Grail Knights can afford the heaviest armor and fastest horses, and have also received the blessings of the Lady of the Lake, the highest honor in Bretonnia. To face down a charging regiment of Grail Knights is to ask for an untimely death.

Bretonnian keeps are built to be bigger, sturdier and more robust than usual. Supposedly, this is so that the lords in charge of the fortresses can better aid and protect the peasants living in their land, as is their duty, but it's more commonly used to protect just the lord, and his own family and possessions, while the peasants have to fare for themselves. Typically, none of the lowborn men-at-arms and free riders are admitted inside, though Bretonnian lords commonly use the empty space to store more weapons and armor to better arm their peasants levies with.

Vampire Knights are a frightening sight to behold to any mortal who has the displeasure of facing them in combat. Augmented by their undead status, they are quick on their feet, and fight with an inhuman ferocity, able to easily cut down two, or even three times their numbers.

Here is where Bretonnia's villages, towns, and cities levy troops to support Bretonnia's nobles during wartime. While numerous, they do not make willing soldiers, and are likely to run if the battle turns sour.

Due to Bretonnia's highly feudalized government and traditions, everyone that is not of noble birth belongs to a noble, with each noble being granted an estate which houses a number of serfs, retinues, and goods. In times of peace, the serfs tend to the noble's fields and the retinues keep a vigilant eye on the surronding lands, patrolling endlessly for malevolent forces. In times of war, a good many of the noble's serfs are levied into his or her's armies, and the retinues are folded into the core knightly units of the noble's army.

Archery is considered dishonorable and ungentlemanly for nobles to practice in the lands of Bretonnia, so such duties are thrust upon the peasantry. Here, Yeomen, both mounted and on foot are practice with their bows and longbows day in and day out. Yeomen are still peasants, so they cannot be trusted to stay on the field if things get hairy, but they can easily harass slower moving targets and deal damage to lightly armored targets.

While all Bretonnian castles house large areas for their knights to practice their combat skills in safety, the cities of Bretonnia play host to gigantic jousting tournies, where knights put their practiced skills to the test against one another. Not only this, but most serfs are forced to accompany their liege to said jousting grounds, forcing some trade between the peasantry of Bretonnia, a rare occurance in most cases.

The Grail monasteries are where all effigies to both the holy Grail and the bloody Grail are housed, and where most nobles come to worship said Grails. Due to the fanatical worship of the Grails, these monasteries are like small castles, heavily fortified and each houses are large contigent of Grail knights, both mounted and dismounted. Due to the peasants being barred from worshipping the Grails, no peasant soldiers can be found inside the halls of the monastery. Instead, the guard unit is made up entirely of noble Grail knights.

Here is where the mighty Grail knights are trained. While many nobles look down upon dismounted combatants, defending the honor of the Grails is of utmost importance, thus this is mostly overlooked when the Grail knights are involved. Stalwart defenders and attackers, Grail knights will fight to the death in service of their Grails.

Here is where the mighty Grail knights are trained. Given the finest steeds, weapons and armor blessed by the Grail itself, these mighty warriors will defend the monastery with their lives. Should a Grail monastery be captured by a vampire, they normally will convert the normal Grail effigies to the Bloody Grail, a similar religious belief, but with obvious vampiric influences.
While most, if not all Damsels travel Bretonnia and the world at large, each monastery is equipped for all the needs a travelling Damsel may require. This includes a large bodyguard retinue.

The Blood Keep is a castle-like structure build near or sometimes on top of a Grail monastery, and acts much like the Damsel quarters of regular Grail monastery. Unlike those, however, these keeps house vampire knights and Blood Grail knights.

Karak Eight Peaks, also known as Vala-Azril-Ungol ( “Queen of the Silver Depths” in Khazalid ), was one of the greatest Dwarf holds, rivaling even Karaz-a-Karak in size and power. It was located in a great bowl-shaped valley, ringed by eight high peaks. Above the surface, walls encompassed a vast area, but most of the city was built below ground. Below the earth, the city was a made up of courts and plazas with great vaulted ceilings, and further below, the tombs of the Dwarf kings and deep mines. Its fall to a combined Skaven-Night Goblin invasion meant the end of the Dwarf Golden Age. Since then, many a member of Clan Angrund has tried to reclaim their ancestral homeland from the vermin infesting it, unsuccessfully..
Asur citizens are known through the world to have a good amount of military training. They have to, as danger lurks even on their continent of Ulthuan.
Asur Wharfs are the life-blood of New world commerce, as most ships must dock in Ulthuan's ports to rest, resupply, and of course, pay fees and tariffs.

Here is where the oldest and most respected of the Asur citizen guards reside, living the life of a minor noble, being able to afford the best equipment, and their desires seen to by servants. Their resolve in battle is legendary, and this inspires other Asur to do the same.
Asur live mostly in or around fortified Mansions and community gathering points, spreading ideas, gossip, and enjoying themselves in relative harmony.

Asur do not build castles or keeps, instead, they build exquisite and luxurious mansions to house themselves, their court, and their servants. Luxury should not be confused for weakness, however, as Asur mansions are very heavily fortified, and are much more resilient and stronger than they look.

Asur armories are where the fablied high Elf blacksmiths, armorsmiths, and fletchers work tirelessly to produce their crafts not only for themselves, but for the citizen militia that uses the items in battle. While not nearly as impressive as Dwarf workship, High Elf worksmanship is nothing to scoff at either.

Most Asur are not known for their horsemenship, that is normally reserved for the riders of Ellyrios, Tiranoc, Caledor, or Cothique, but there are some of the lesser nobility that can afford to practice this art form.

Every Asur noble worth his salt has at least some Asur craftsman or woman in their court, from Jewelsmiths to Artists and even Furniture designers, all in the name of increasing their standing in Asur society. This also has the added bonus of increasing trade and buisness near the Mansion, and spreading new techniques and ideas to the settlemant.

Avelorn is homeland of the Everqueens and spiritual center of all Asur folk. As such, it's nobility spend more wealth on equiping and training their citizen Militia than most of realms within Ulthuan.

Avelorn is homeland of the Everqueens and spiritual center of all Asur folk. As such, it's nobility spend more wealth on equiping and training their citizen Militia than most of realms within Ulthuan.
The Sisters of Avelorn are the Everqueen's elite bodyguards, designated to protect their Everqueen whatever the cost. They also make for elite soldiers in Avelorni hosts.

Caledor is a realm of great martial prowess and pride, reflected in their Silver-Helm and Dragon Prince Riders. Their Militia forces composed of dismounted Riders, and while they do not have their mounts, they are strong opponents none the less.

Silver-Helm riders are the fists of Asur armies, charging valiantly into enemy lines, crushing those that dare stand in their way. Caledori Silver-Helms are no different in that regard, but are more experienced, and have better equipment than most other Helms.

Caledor is known for many things, but above all are it's Dragon Princes. Composed of lesser and highborn nobility, Dragon Princes are fearsome sights to behold, and strike at their enemies with astonishing grace and confidence, every strike hitting it's mark.

Chrace is a heavily forest realm, and also lies on the invasion path for malekith's constant incursions into Ulthuan. Due to this, the Militia of Chrace is well prepared for war, providing stout arms for the defense of Ulthuan.

Chrace is a heavily forest realm, and also lies on the invasion path for malekith's constant incursions into Ulthuan. Due to this, the Militia of Chrace is well prepared for war, providing stout arms for the defense of Ulthuan.

The White-Lions of Chrace are an elite heavy infantry fighting force, from the forests of Chrace. To become a White-Lion, one must go deep into the forests of Chrace and slay a white Lion, and take the pelt for oneself.

Cothique is one of the outer realms of Ulthuan, and one of the most populous of realms. Due to this advantage, Cothique's Militia levies are much larger than the other realms', but are less well equipped. This does not make them any less potent, however, as Cothique supplies Ulthuan with her Mariners for her navy.

Cothique's primary speciality is fishing, and not just fishing, but Sailory as well. Cothique Marines are some of the finest in all of Ulthuan, rivaled only by the Lothern Seaguard, and more than a match for Dark Elf Corsairs. Cothiq Marines are also some of Cothique's more well equipped troops, and can take quite a punishing before being forced to retreat.

Eatainian Seaguards are, without a doubt, the finest sailors Ulthuan can muster. Unsavory by High Elf standards, these grim marines are a tough fighting force, capable of fighting on sea and land, whenever the need arises. With Lothern being such a significant port in the New World, it needs to be.
Lothern is not known to have horsemanship traditions, so more often than not, these cavalrymen are imported from Ellyrion and Chrace to supplement it's Militia forces with cavalry.

Lothern is the center of all trading in the New World, nothing comes or goes without consent from Ulthuan, and Lothern's Trading Companies are the first responders to all outsiders wishing to make port, whether it be to sell, buy, or just passing by.

Ellyrion is a realm of flowing hills and long plains, perfect for cavalry warfare. Thus, Ellyrion does not field a massive foot-based army, instead fielding a large cavalry-centric army. Ellyrion Reavers are some of the finest skirmisher cavalry in the world, and it's light cavalry support is never far from the stragglers, picking them off as they run.

Equipped with the best light armor, swords, and bows, and given some of the fastest and strongest horses, Ellyrion Reavers are deadly skirmisher cavalry units that harry and harass enemy lines, and cut down routed units.

The Shadowlands are all that remains of the wonderous realm of Nagarythe, homeland of the Dark Elfs. It is a broken, and sparsly populated land, instead of civilized Asur principles, the land is governed by the Shadow warriors, bitter nomadic warriors that are reknown for their gurrella style warfare and their skills with bow and blade.

The Shadowlands are a tough and merciless land, where civilization is shunned, and a nomadic exsistance presuded. But from these hardships arise warriors of steel and shadow, tempered by their homeland, Nagarythi Shadow Warriors are expert swordsmen and archers, able to strike at the most unexpected of times and places, Dark Elf invaders rightly fear invading through the shadowlands, and even their Asur brothers distrust them.

Saphery is one of the inner kingdoms of Ulthuan, home to most of Ulthuan's master mages and swordsmen. Due to this large pool of experience and knowledge in both spellcasting and warfare, Saphery troops are less militia, and more trained, professional soldiers instead.

Sapherian Phoenix guards are the elite guards of high ranking Elf officials, or elite soldiers for Elf war hosts. Masters of their craft, they are bound by magic to never speak, and are eternally loyal to their superiors.

When there comes a problem that the local Elf militia units cannot handle, the task falls upon the best swordsmen in all the realsm of Ulthuan, the Swordmasters of Hoeth. Spending decades, even centuries perfecting their mastery over the blade, these champions of Ulthuan are the hammer of any Ulthuan host.

Tiranoc is the western most realm of Ulthuan, and is also a realm that shows great interest in the outside world, but unlike Eatainia, Tiranoc is not interested in trading or helping the natives, instead, they wish to expand Elf influence at the cost of the native population's influence. As a result, Tiranoc is not as populated as most other realms, but isn't so severly depopulated as to match Yvress in lack of population.

To live in Yvresse is to fight all of your life, and so its inhabitants are well prepared for any conflict.

The primary -and only- defense against seaborn enemies, the military wharf is where Asuryan ships come to dock for repairs, supplies, or extra sailors or marines for their ships.
The lifeblood of the colony, this port allows for goods to pass from the colony to Ulthuan, whether it be building materials, foodstuffs, or even soldiers or people.

Asuryan plantations are responsible for extracting the resources that an Asuryan colony needs to survive. They are highly defended much like Asuryan mansions, and can house hundreds of servants, nobles, and resources to send back to Ulthuan

While the mighty plantations that dot an Asuryan colony's lands are responsible for extracting resources from said land, the guild headquarters is what packages and preps the goods for trade. Full of talented individuals, the headquarters is also a good place for refinement of economic ideas.

While the armies of Ulthuan are more levy styled, being raised  whenever war calls, the armies of Ulthuan's colonys are more along the lines of Professional soldiers. They are payed a handsome salery and their accomidations and supplies are payed for by the reigning lord governor. This allows Asuryan colonies to react quickly to different situations, such as Druchii raids or if Ulthuan calls for her colonies' assitance.

Chrace is a heavily forest realm, and also lies on the invasion path for malekith's constant incursions into Ulthuan. Due to this, the Militia of Chrace is well prepared for war, providing stout arms for the defense of Ulthuan.
