The Sisters of Avelorn are the Everqueen's elite bodyguards, designated to protect their Everqueen whatever the cost. They also make for elite soldiers in Avelorni hosts.

While the Asur of Ulthuan live in beautifully decorated mansions, full of life and brilliant colors, their forsaken kin, the Druchii, live in great fortresses of black, oily stone and depressing colors. The sadism of the Druchii is legendary, and their fortresses reflect this, full of hate and malice towards all life, only the Druchii could bare to live in such a miserable place.

Druchii fortress walls, nicknamed Walls of Malice for their intimidating and striking appearance, are pitch black walls of great height and volume, surronding a Druchii fortress or city in a circular shape. Much like the places they protect, they are designed to scare opponents and offer new ways of torture for the Druchii's victims.
Bleakswords are the Druchii's elite rank-and-file swordsmen units, designed to take and hold objectives and tie down enemy units in combat.

The Autarii are the descendents of the Nagarythi that stayed loyal to Malekith and fled with him to Naggaroth. Legends say that they shunned settling in the major cities of the Druchii, and took to a more brutal, and feral life in the dark wilderness of Naggaroth. Due to this lifestyle, all shades are masters of the forests they patrol, and can silently stalk prey for miles, on top of being crack shots with their bows. When Malekith campaigns in Ulthuan, a great number of shades accompany him, and most remain when he is defeated, causing great trouble for the Phoenix kings.
The Dread Keep is where the Dreadspears and Darkshards gather and train in spear and crossbow, but in the grand scheme of things they serve as little more than fodder for the meatgrinder.

The Spire of Depravity is where much of the wickedness and foul things go on inside a Druchii fortress. All sorts of persons, be they slaves, prisoners of war, or even family members, are processed in the spire to determine their use, so what passes for trade happens here.

Cold Ones are reptilian creatures from the cold wastes of northern Naggaroth, tamed and trained by the Druchii to act as heavy cavalry. Their savage nature complements their riders personalities, so little is left standing after a Cold One charge. Due to long standing rivalries between cold one riders and darkriders, cold one riders will refuse to even be in the same province as the darkriders, and so their stable cannot be built if you already have darkriders.

Darkriders are the light cavalry counterpart to the cold one knights, being armed with swords and bows, and riding horses into battle instead of cold ones. They are used primarily to harass and run down routing units, but they also are good at running down skirmishers. Due to a deep and old rivalry between the cold one knights, their stables cannot be built in the same provinces as the cold ones.

Beastpens are where the High Beastmasters keep their quarry, beasts ranging from Manticores, Cold Ones, even Hydras and Kharibdyss, all bred for war and slaughter in the name of their sadistic masters.

The Autarii live a hard life in the deep dark of the lands of chill, so those that live to be of an elder age are a rare sight. Venerable shades are faster, smarter, and deadlier than the regular shades, and many hold positions of power within the hiearchy of the Autarii clans.

The Blackguard are the elite bodyguard regiments of Malekith, made up of the sons of the Druchii nobility. They are equipped with the best armor and weapons, and are disciplined into the most loyal, perfect killing machine, feeling no remorse as they cut down those that stand against the Witch King. While the Witch King fields the largest amount of Blackguards, other Druchii lords have fielded their own versions of the blackguard in their personal retinues.

Due to Clar Karond's position inside the Dark Forest, it has ample resources to construct the grand fleets of Naggaroth. Thanks to this, The feared Black Ark corsairs can attack and pillage anywhere in the world, bringing back more slaves for Naggaroth

Har Ganeth, the city of executioners, is a city entirely devoted to Khaela Mensha Khaine and headquarters to the executioners and has the largest amount of Witch Elves out of all other cities. Many of the Witch Elves that reside in the city are the elite, elder members of the covens, capable of taking down scores of enemies with minimal effort.

Ghrondari, the tower of sorcery, is a grand fortress in the north of Naggaroth that houses the sorceresses of Naggaroth, the only persons allowed to practice magic, reigning down powerful spells to decitmate enemy armies.

All Druchii fortresses and cities have a place devoted to their slaves, but Hag Graef's economy subsist entirely upon it's slaves, and so each has a larger stock of slaves than the other cities. These slaves are not only used to toil in mines, but also as fodder for the cities' armies.

While Karond Kar may be more known for it's corsairs and as the entry point for slaves into Naggaroth, Karond has a tradition of fielding gigantic warbeasts from the western side of the Blackspine mountains. These creatures are larger and stronger than those found on the eastern side of the mountain, and may a beastmaster has died trying to break these creatures for the lords of Karond Kar.

Witch Elves are masochistic female dark elves that have a talent for slaughter. They are lightly armored troops, but thanks to their speed and lethality, they can be quite difficult to defeat in battle.

Druchii temples are foul places, dark stains on an already darkened land. Here is where the bloody sacrifices and slaugher to Khaela Mensha Kaine and other Cytharai gods are done, and also where the witch elves and sorceresses call their home.

Here is where the mighty of sorceresses of Ghrond make there home in this temple. Well trained in the wind of Dhar, these spellcasters can make short work of regiments while support the Druchii armies from behind.

A section of the temple has been entirely devoted to the worship of Ereth Khial, the Elven goddess of the savage hunt and ruler of the Elven underworld. The pale queen is a jealous goddess, and constantly seeks to be the ruler of the Elven pantheon and to take all Elven souls. Due to this, the temple is fortified with an undead garrison, and it's walls hardened, making it more difficult to assault.

A section of the temple has been devoted entirely to the worship of Khaela Mensha Khaine, the Elven god of war and murder. The bloody handed god embodies the Druchii's murderous instincts, as such the shrine will provide bonuses to the Witch Elves and sorceresses, augmenting their combat skills and equipment.

A section of the temple has been devoted entirely to the worship of Mathlann, the Elven god of the ocean and all the creatures that live in it. The lord of the deeps is a fickle and destructive god, but appeasing him will allow the temple to field warbeasts and galleys.

The great Black Ark ships are massive warships used by the Druchii to pillage and plunder all across the world, and in times of war, also function as massive transport ships, moving large warhosts from Naggaroth to Ulthuan with great speed. Due to the sheer size of these ships, the Druchii have used these ships to set up minor settlements all across the world, spreading the influence of Malekith and the Dark Elves far and wide.

Unlike their more 'civilized' cousins in and near the great cities of Naggaroth, the feral Druchii are organized in clan units, with each clan contributing a certain amount of warriors when called upon. Due to the rudimentary nature of the feral Druchii, this system makes it very prone for entire clans to be annihilated in wars, due to rivals sending the entire families into battles...

The Autarii are a subgroup of 'feral' Druchii that inhabit the dark wilderness of Naggaroth and the Blackspine mountains. Their families are organized into clans, each of which can trace it's lineage back to the original two thousand Druchii that refused to settle in the six founding cities. Due to the climate and lands that Autarii inhabit, most live semi-nomadic lives, moving from place to place depending upon whether or not their camp is compromised to a rival tribe or not.

Like all Druchii, the Autarii are a morally deprived lot, and eagerly take slaves of all sorts in their wars and raids, forcing them to march without rest back to their camps, only to be sold to the Druchii that inhabit the cities of Naggaroth. Unlike those urban Druchii, however, is that they do not use their slaves for manual labor or as fodder, as they believe that it shames them and would lead them to becoming soft.

Here is where the Autarii organize the many clans of their tribes into warhosts. Each clan contributes a certain amount of clanmembers to the host, but each can choose which profession they wish to excel in, the bow, the sword, or the spear. This allows Autarii warhosts to tackle a variety of different threats to their security and freedom, should the need arise.

The Blackspine mountains are a large mountain range to the west of Naggaroth, where many ferocious and foul creatures call home. To the west of these mountains lie vast deserts and volcanic wastelands, of which the most dangerous and titanic of beasts live. Many Autarii consider taming these creatures a serious honor, and bringing one back to the tribe inbues the clanmember and his clan with a great deal of prestige, while the tribe is strengthened by such creatures in their ranks.

The great slave markets of the Druchii are places of pain and depravity, where the master's leash cuts deep and the very air thick with malice. Here, slaves are corraled into various stocks and pens, awaiting their fates, weither it be to die toiling in mines, dying in battle, or worse yet, becoming another plaything for their new Druchii masters.

Druchii ports are reknown for being unscrupulus places, full of scum and villany, even for Druchii standards. Home to the Black Ark Corsairs, these ports are bustiling with trade, but most of the trade that does go on is between slavers and their products.

Darkriders are the light cavalry counterpart to the cold one knights, being armed with swords and bows, and riding horses into battle instead of cold ones. They are used primarily to harass and run down routing units, but they also are good at running down skirmishers.

While the Asur of Ulthuan live in beautifully decorated mansions, full of life and brilliant colors, their forsaken kin, the Druchii, live in great fortresses of black, oily stone and depressing colors. The sadism of the Druchii is legendary, and their fortresses reflect this, full of hate and malice towards all life, only the Druchii could bare to live in such a miserable place.

The Black Ark Corsairs are some of the most feared marauders in the world, able to strike anywhere, at any time, and vanish as quickly as they arrived. In times of war, when they are not harassing trade and supply lanes, they will join up with Druchii armies to act as heavy infantry units.
Mourkain is the ancient capital of Strygos, a multi-tiered fortress radiating lost glory from its every edifice.
Strigany are masters of the art of trade, and here is where it is done. If merchants and travellers don't come to the Strigany to trade, the Strigany will come to them.
These lands are vast, and mostly untouched by settled civilization. Perhaps we would encourage nomads to move into this province, and levy them into our army for future wars.
The need to retain Strygos' independance and security means that Strygan fortresses are designed to house large amounts of soldiers and withstand severe punishment from beseiging armies.

Strygan cities are fortresses in their own right. Built out of necessity, they are built to withstand everything from greenskin migrations to Bretonnian crusades. Even with the Badlands under the control of the greenskins, the ruins of old Strygos have endured to this day. We can replicate the masterworks of old Strygos and build these new fortress cities in our provinces, so that we may never fall again.

Strygans are masters of defense, and Strygan Murder-Gates are their magnum opus. Utilising a maze-like network of defensive walls and gates, Strygans are able to corral invaders through a gauntlet of withering fire from above while creating the impression that respite is just around the next corner. But it's not, boiling tar is.
The Mess Hall is the heart of all ogre hordes, it is where they gather to feast, revel, and make merry.

While wrestling and eating are the more preferred ways of showing who's the boss in an ogre horde, another popular game of skill and strength is to hurl enormous rocks as far as one can. Anyone crushed by the sudden death from above is a welcome snack.
Mead, ale, and beer are all important drinks for an ogre horde. To have a shortage of any of the three would lead to fighting amongst the ogres, instead of fighting other enemies.

Ogres are famously good at two things, eating and looting. They're also quite adept at cobbling together whatever they need from natural resources or the ruins of other civilisations. Building up our foraging parties will ensure that our host has more than enough to go around, whether it be food or weapons.
Ogre hosts are known to employ large bands of hobgoblins and gnoblars, acting as fodder, skirmishers, or light cavalry support.

Long ago, These lands were filled with ancient structures devoted to the Old Ones, our masters. While they are long gone, their cities that they built for us remain, a testiment to our will to carry out their orders. Perhaps with enough time, we can restore these lands to what they once were.
Our lands are ever threatened by the arrogant, younger races whom wish to impede our masters' plans. We must arm ourselves if we are to carry out our sacred orders.
We must not forget our place and purpose, the reason we were put on this world, and what our orders are, something that only the Custodian Skinks can do.
While our ruins may lack a spawning pool that the more developed Pyramid-cities and Temple-cities have, we can still deploy Saurus warriors for our armies to act as elite troops.
The Great Old Ones are gone, but their imagery and relics are not, and our Skink scouts have managed to collect some ruined relics from a long lost past.
Our collection of Old One relics grows, chief! Even now, our Custodians drone over the relics, making sure that each and every one is maintained, lest they be lost forever.

Lizardmen Pyramid-Cities are heavily armed and fortified cities shaped like pyramids, which dot the Lustrian and Southland jungles. A large majority of Old One relics and Lizardmen are stored or stocked up in these cities, leading some to call them 'Cities of gold' or 'Lost cities'.

Much like most of the Lizardmen's architecture, the Pyramid-City's walls are of Old one design, making them some of the more stronger structures in the world. They have to be, as more often than not these cities are full of relics, treasures, and sometimes even Slann themselves.

While most Skinks are delegated to more civil tasks, such as Administrating and record keeping, Skinks are far from useless on the battlefield, and are often fielded in Lizardmen armies to act as light troops or skirmishers.

Saurus warrior broods are the most common sights in a Lizardman army, making up a majority of it's forces. Sauri are, quite literally, bred for war, and as such, can wield the more heavier weapons, and are generally stronger than Skinks, making them the frontline heavy infantry of Lizardmen armies.

Like the rest of their armies, and realms for that matter, Lizardmen cavalry units are quadrupedal(or flying) reptilians that spawned from a Pyramid-City's spawning pool. Most Lizardman 'cavalry' units are cold ones, mounted by Saurus warriors, but Terradons can also be considered 'cavalry'.

Kroxigors are bigger, stronger, and dumber versions of Skinks, equivelent to giants in old world terms. In times of peace, they are used as construction workers, but in times of war, these lumbering beasts are used as heavy shock troops, sent crashing into enemy lines to great affect.
While most Lizardman cities have large amounts of Old One relics, Skinks will still construct their own offerings, apparel, and trinkets in honor of the Old Ones.

Every Pyramid-City of the Lizardmen has a specific section devoted to the storage and upkeep of Old One and Skink relics and trinkets. More often than not, however, these areas are targeted by plundering adventurers, seeking riches and fame.

The Lost Lizardmen are an off-shoot of the Southland Lizardmen created by the Old Ones long ago to keep the Eastern lands in check, but have long since lost their Slann, sending them into a serious regression of skills. These Sanctuaries are all that remains of any serious Old One influence.
Scar-Guards are the elite of the elite, the finest of all Saurus warriors. They also happen to be the oldest, and are generally bodyguards for high-ranking skinks or for their Slann overlords.

The Southlands are a harsh, hostile, and generally unexplored place. Rumor has it that the Southland Lizardman spawning pools are capable of spawning stronger, more monstrous versions of Terradons, Kroxigors, and Cold Ones.

While most believe that the Lizardmen mostly inhabit the dry ground of Lustria, there have been reports and sightings from pirates, adventurers, and the odd merchant sons that creatures of vast size lurk beneath the warm waters of Lustria, able to easily snap merchant ships in half, and rumored to devour Krakens whole. The Imperials call these creatures the Mosasaur, and it is believed that they are mostly used to transport Lizardman armies from Lustria to the old world, should the Slann demand it. It is also rumored that these creatures can traverse land, but this is unconfirmed...
While most Temple-cities do not field large amounts of soldiers for armies, a majority of a Temple-City's fielded forces are Skink skirmishers, which can act as screens or harrying forces.

While Pyramid-Cities can be considered Military bases in old world terms, Temple-Cities are the major population centers of the Lizardmen. Hundreds, sometimes even thousands of various Lizardmen live inside the City's walls, carrying out the Old Ones' orders, as told by their regents, the Slann.
While most Saurus warrior broods are sent to Pyramid-Cities to await further orders, Temple-Cities still maintain small bands of Saurus warriors to act as elite warriors for their armies.

Much like most of the Lizardmen's architecture, the Temple-City's walls are of Old one design, making them some of the more stronger structures in the world. They have to be, as more often than not these cities are full of relics, treasures, and sometimes even Slann themselves.
We must not forget our place and purpose, the reason we were put on this world, and what our orders are, something that only the Custodian Skinks can do.

Temple-Complexes are the grand palaces of the new world, the largest, and most grandest of Old One buildings are seen here, as more often than not, these complexes house a Slann, a large toad-like creature of impossible magical powers, and regents of the Old Ones. Only they can piece together the Great Plan, and lead the Lizardmen to their destiny as care-takers of the world.
Much like Pyramid-Cities, Temple-Complexes do not house large amounts of Skinks, but a good many of the Skinks that are housed in the complexes serve skimisher or light infantry roles.

Unlike the regular Saurus warrior broods seen around Lizardmen holdings, Saurus temple guard broods are larger, deadlier, and older Saurus warriors, normally hand picked by Slann to serve in entourage whenever the Great Plan calls for it.

Much like anything near Temple-Complexes, Skink master custodians are older, wiser Skinks that preserve Old One relics and texts, and if a Slann is present in the temple, then they are also his caretakers and servants.
While much of the Old Ones' tech is either beyond repair or lost, some of it still remains, and with the proper knowledge, can be worked again to increase the fighting power of our armies.

If Scar-Guards are the elite warriors of Pyramid-Cities, then temple Scar-Guards are the elite of all Lizardmen troops. Given the best equipment possible, lead by the oldest and best among their ranks, and tasked with defending their Slann masters even at the cost of their lives means that these units are like mountains on the battlefield, unweavering and immovable.

The grand mausoleums of the Nehekharans are the final resting places for the Khemri Tomb King's common servants from ages past. Buried by the hundreds or thousands, these subjects served their masters loyaly in life, and are now condemed to serve them forever in undeath. With most of regular life gone due to Nagash's curse, a large amount of the commoners buried in these mausoleums are soldiers, waiting to be awakened by their master's call to war.

Nehekharan Tombs are normally divided into sections, with each housing a different class of subject or servant in said sections. Here is where the archer core of a Nehekharan army is buried, waiting for the time they are awakened.

Much like the Archer burial chambers, these chambers house the spear units of the Nehekharan armies. They are the most basic and numerous of the Nehekharan infantry units, and are good at holding down other infantry blocks and stopping cavalry charges.

Due to the need to bury their steeds with them, these servants of the Tomb Kings are buried in a seperate mausoleum. While not the most impressive cavalry, these units are still feared on the battlefield, for they never tire nor run from battle.

The chariot is a weapon of war almost as old as mankind itself, having originated and seen extensive use in old Nehekhara, being used to crash into dense infantry blocks and disrupt their lines. With every living soul in Nehekhara dead, an adaptation was adopted for the chariots, adding scythes to the hubs of the wheels so that when the chariots crash into the undead ranks, they truly are scattered.

Hundreds, if not thousands of necropoli and mausoleums dot Nehekhara's landscape, the final resting place for many of the Tomb King's servants. While not nearly as impressive as the Tomb King's burial sites, the commoner's necropoli are still very large, and house not only the dead buried there, but also things like gems, coins, jewlery, even pottery.

Nehekhara is an old civilization, having long exsisted before the age of castles and gunpowder. As such, the Tomb Kings do not have 'walls' to defend their resting places, but instead rely upon the thousand year old traps that have been built into their burial sites. A determined would-be adventurer can circumvent and defeat the traps, navigating an army's worth of men and/or women is much more difficult.

In the ages past, Nehekhara had absolute naval dominance in the southern lands of the old-world. Her ships traveled far and wide, spreading Nehekharan borders and culture from the Southlands and even as far as the Empire in the north. While the Tomb Kings may have no need for trade, they do this anyway, to help live out their dilusions of being alive again.

While the commoners lie buried in mausoleums and necropoli, the royalty and priesthood of Nehekhara live Grand pyramid complexes, each being bigger than the last in an attempt to out do each other in the after-life. Inside the staggeringly huge buildings are thousands of rooms, each laden with either servants, precious treasures, or the Tomb King or Liche-priest itself sometimes. Due to the status of those buried in these structures, they are full of traps and cryptic puzzles, and few can say they have successfully plundered such a building.

In life, these servants of the Liche-priests would have helped prepare Nehekharans for their journeys to the after-life, mummifying them and sealing them in sarcophagi, and sending the body to their final resting place. Now, they are mindless servants to the Liche-priests, their only goal is the protection of the priest itself.

column3: While most highborn nobles get their own mausoleums for them to rest eternally in, the lower end of the nobles, priesthood included, must be placed inside the Liche-priest Mortuary, so that the priests could be defend and served in the afer-life. Even with Nagash's curse, these nobles and priests defend their masters and to their bidding when commanded. Heavily armed and armored, these troops are much more threatening then the regular hosts of the Tomb Kings.

column2: While the Liche-priests are tasked with upkeeping the undead Nehekharan servants, they also have the job of assembling the monstrous statues fielded by Tomb Kings. Here is where they practice this craft, melding sandstone together with magic to give the statues life, so that they may better serve their masters in combat.

Much like their royal counterparts, Liche-priests are buried in magnificent tomb structures that house not only themselves, but their creations, servants, precious gems, and above all, their manuscripts and knowledge scrolls. Due to their huge importance in undead life, their tombs are normally secluded, and well protected so that they may rise again to serve the Tomb Kings in death, as they did in life.

Unlike the grand pyramids that the priesthood and royalty inhabit, those undead that dwell in the old Nehekharan cities 'live' and 'rest' in the ancient buildings of old Nehekhara, in an attempt to get back to some normalcy. Here are where the skimisher units of Nehekhara's armies reside, training again old, decayed dummies, gathering in their mess halls for long decayed food that they cannot eat, and returning to their resting quarters, as if they still required sleep.

Grand Necropoli are what remains of the ancient Nehekharan cities of old. While in their pasts, they may have been luxurious cities of gold and plenty, but now all that remains are hollowed husks of citizens and buildings alike. After the curse of Nagash brought the Tomb Kings back to life, many have tried to return to their old ways, some going so far as to order their servants to gather water from long dried up wells, or to hold feasts full of food and wine that none can taste.

Here is where the ancient pike regiments of old Nehekhara dwell. Much like with anything in Nehekhara's cities, these places are mockeries of life they once held, where the mindless servants of the Tomb Kings drone and toil in their barracks, trying to live the life they once had.

While the Tomb Kings and Liche-priests rest inside proper mausoleums or pyramids, guarded by their traps and unknown-ness, Nehekharan cities are well known and established places, and have been around for millenia, and their walls are no exception to this. What might have once been a clean, brightly colored and highly decorated wall is now covered in sand and dust, and decayed from the millenia these walls have had to endure. While they may be old, these wall should not be mistaken for being weak and ready to collapse, for much like the pyramids, these cities were built to stand the test of time.

Ancient Nehekharans deeply understood and honored archery, with most of the nobility and even commoners knowing how to use a bow properly, and here, in those ancient days, would the Nehekharans practice the art of horse archery. Now, with the unliving rising again from their tombs, the horse archers of old return to their stables, awaiting their master's call to arms.

In times long past, Nehekhara had a thriving trade scene, with many exotic goods flowing in and out of her cities, making the Tomb Kings very rich in life. Now, in death, these marketplaces serve only as reminders of that long lost past glory, to which they still cling, some going as far as to have their subjects 'trade' and 'use' the market squares like they once did.

Unlike the luxurious and mastercrafted resting grounds of the royal and priestly Tomb Kings, the commoner's were mostly buried in necropoli such as these, which would house hundreds, sometimes thousands of servants and inhabitants of the cities. While they may not have nearly as much treasure or protection as the other burial grounds, these necropoli are still heavily trapped and occupied.

While all Nehekharans have long since perished and reawakened as the undead Tomb Kings, Nehekhara is still called home by nomadic arabyan tribes that roam from oasis to oasis. They are technically our subjects, and as such we can count on them to colonize lands for us.

The Black Pyramid of Nagash was  built under the reign of the sorcerer Nagash, by uncounted slaves brought to Khemri from all over Nehekhara. It was made of stone the colour of ebony, which Nagash demanded from all the cities of Nehekhara. Not just a monument to Nagash's pride, the pyramid was painstakingly designed to store death magic and to amplify Nagash's powers.

In the cold reaches of the Northern Chaos Wastes roam innummerable tribes of evil men whom serve the Dark Gods. Most of the time, these countless tribes are divided and fight amongst themselves, trying to win the favor of their gods. Sometimes, however, there rises a cheiftain of one of the tribes with the power to win the hearts of mortal men, and the strength to carry the gifts of their Dark Gods, and unites the tribes of the north under his or her banner, and will eventually begin marching southward in an attempt to tred the civilized world under their boots.

The thick outer walls of a Chaos Dwarf Fortress are made out of the same dark obsidian as the rest of the structure. As a sign of defiance to the enemies of the Dawi-Zharr, huge carved statues of Great Taurus and Lammasu flank the gates and entrances to the forts.

The Chaos Dwarf Fortresses are huge bastions build in the desolate Dark Lands to maintain control and power over the vast wasteland. The fortresses of the Dawi-Zharr are build from obsidian and huge blocks of volcanic lava rocks.
A weapon both cunning and brutal, the Fire-Glaive is a testament of the greatness of the Dawi Zharr, a compact, heavily constructed repeating handgun.
Chaos Dwarf armies feature a lot of slave dregs, "recruited" from all races,  driven against their foes in great herds - ironically for the purpose of obtaining even more slaves.

Thanks to the combination of industrial and magical prowess, the Chaos Dwarfs are able to construct massive fleets in a matter of years, which are then used to transport their slaver armies across the world in search of fresh slaves for their countless factories and endless sacrifices.

The Chaos Dwarf Slaver Outposts lack walls or any kind of heavy fortifications, relying instead on a system of Hobgoblin watchers who guard their slaving operations from atop sturdy black-iron watchtowers.

The Chaos Dwarfs have set up numerous outposts all across the Dark Lands and beyond in order to secure more slaves for their wicked industry. These outposts usually lack the defenses or garrisons of the Ziggurat-Temples and the Obsidian Fortresses, depending mostly on the local Hobgoblin enforcers and Chaos Dwarf taskmasters to guard the slavery operations of the Dawi-Zharr.
This is where the Chaos Dwarf taskmasters get trained and equipped with the best weapons from the Dawi Zharr forge factories.

The most favoured out of all the servants of the Chaos Dwarfs, the Hobgoblins from the eastern steppes are adept at riding the giant wolves the prowl their native lands. They will usually follow Dawi Zharr armies on their campaigns of slave raiding, and herd their slaves afterwards as overseers.

The Chaos Dwarfs are the undisputed masters of mass industry. In their Slave Outposts one can find that the land is choked with pits of molten tar, rivers of burning oil, massive stockpiles of coal and other effluence of industry, pock-marked with countless pits and mines and home to many thousands of workshops and factories.

Thanks to the combination of industrial and magical prowess, the Chaos Dwarfs are able to construct massive fleets in a matter of years, which are then used to transport their slaver armies across the world in search of fresh slaves for their countless factories and endless sacrifices.

The Hell-Workers are a caste within Chaos Dwarf society charged with the maintenance and supervision of the Dawi-Zharr factories. Not as inventive as the Daemon-Smiths, their work is to make sure that the slave dregs keep on manufacturing the terrible war machines and wicked weaponry.

Chaos Dwarf Slaver Guilds are very much similar to their none corrupted brethern guilds, in that each hall contains a retinues, clansmen, and goods. What is different about them however, is the excessive amount of magma, effigies to Hashut, and the Daemonsmith Arcanium, normally located in the deep within the guild halls, so that the Daemonsmiths may not be disturbed.

Here is where the slaver's guild's retinues are housed and trained. Mostly composed of relatives, extended or not, they form the elite guard units of the guild, and are normally tasked with defending the guild's assets, leaving the actual slaving to their Hobgoblin servants.

The treacherous Hobgoblin slavers are quartered here. Untrustworthy, even by Goblin standards, Hobgoblins serve the Chaos Dwarfs as warriors, servants, and slavers in exchange for riches and protection from other Greenskins, whom have a special hatred of the Hobgoblins for betraying them during their rebellion against the Chaos Dwarfs.

The Daemonsmith Arcanium is the center of anything and everything related to Hashut, from worship to sacrificing. Here, the Daemonsmiths meld Daemon with machine, creating fearsome warmachines for the guild. While not nearly of the same quality of make that the sorcerer-prophets have, these machines are still better than what most Daemonsmiths can create.

The Ironsworn are the elite counterparts to the Infernal Guard. Armed with the deadly fireglaive, these warriors can fire from a distance, and defend themselves should the enemy get close to them. Unlike the normal retinues of the guild, these units are not normally seen in the field, unless the safety of the guild is threatened.

Like all Greenskin races, the Hobgoblins are lead by the most cunning and brutal of their kind, in this case, a Hobgoblin Khan. The Khan functions much like a Warboss, but unlike the other Greenskin races, the title of Khan will pass between Hobgoblins at an alarmingly fast rate, as every Hobgoblin deserves to lead and rule over everyone else.

A slaver's guild hall is not complete without it's very own industrial drydock. Here, mighty foundries pump out and assemble all parts needed to create the mighty fleets of the Chaos Dwarfs, so that they may hunt for their quarry across the entire world.

While most Human architecture cannot compete with those of the elder races, the Imperials can say with pride that theirs are fairly close to dwarf stock. Elegant, yet intimidating, Imperial castles are normally situated on points of strategic importance, such as river forks or high Plateaus. Like Tilean palaces of the south, Imperial castles have a small cadre of artists, scientists, and engineers to upkeep the castle.

The armory is one of the main pieces of any Imperial castle or city, used to house all of the armor and weapons that will later be used to equip the province's militia units. This one lacks any sort of proper equipment, diminishing the militia's fighting abilities.

The armory is one of the main pieces of any Imperial castle or city, used to house all of the armor and weapons that will later be used to equip the province's militia units. This one has weapons of some quality in it's stock, improving the fighting abilities of the province's militia.

The armory is one of the main pieces of any Imperial castle or city, used to house all of the armor and weapons that will later be used to equip the province's militia units. This one has weapons of superb quality in it's stock, greatly improving the fighting abilities of the province's militia.

Unlike the State Troops, whom are professional soldiers payed to fight, Free Companies are composed almost entirely of militia, that is, hunters, farmers, and so on. While they are not trained to fight, and are not as well equipped as the State Troops, Free Companies are normally raised when times are dire, and so these might fight for their homes, instead of money.

Unlike the State Troops, whom are professional soldiers payed to fight, Free Companies are composed almost entirely of militia, that is, hunters, farmers, and so on. While they are not trained to fight, and are not as well equipped as the State Troops, Free Companies are normally raised when times are dire, and so these might fight for their homes, instead of money.

The Empire is full of forests and woodlands, some of which are more dangerous than others. From these places the Imperials recruit their archers, dead accurate with their bows, they are nothing to scoff at.

Like their Bretonnian counterparts, Imperial castles will normally have villages and hamlets outside their walls, for the castle can provide some safety to the villagers below. Unlike their Bretonnian counterparts, however, is that these villagers can move around freely, stimulating trade and spreading new ideas throughout the Empire.

In the Empire, education is taken more seriously among the nobility than in other regions such as Bretonnia or Tilea and Estalia. As such, a cadre of academicians and engineers is common place in the castles of the Empire.

In the Empire, education is taken more seriously among the nobility than in other regions such as Bretonnia or Tilea and Estalia. As such, a cadre of academicians and engineers is common place in the castles of the Empire.

The Grand Order of the Reiksguard are a prestigious, elite order of knights that fight for any emperor of the Reikland or Reiklander emperor. Their ranks are open to everyone, but only the best of the best are chosen to join their ranks, and the effect this has on their units is seen in the field. Utterly loyal, brilliant warriors, and unwavering in the face of evil, these riders are a force to be reckoned with.

The Grand Order of the Reiksguard are a prestigious, elite order of knights that fight for any emperor of the Reikland or Reiklander emperor. Their ranks are open to everyone, but only the best of the best are chosen to join their ranks, and the effect this has on their units is seen in the field. Utterly loyal, brilliant warriors, unwavering in the face of evil, and crack shots, these foot soldiers are a force to be reckoned with.

Due to the Reikland's position in the Empire, and places such as Ubersreik, Bogenhafen, and Altdorf, the Reikland is a very rich place, and many nobles and emperors have used this wealth to build large armories for their soldiers.
Thanks to Nuln, Wissenlander militias can maintain regiments of black powder troops, armed with the famous Nuln repeating rifle.
Due to bordering both the Black and Grey mountains, Wissenland has access to a large amount of metals, which allows them to fortify their walls and better protect their soldiers

With Nuln being a major trading hub in the southern Empire, there are many trade routes to and from the city, and each requires a guard to protect the merchants and travellers. In times of war, these riders can be levied into the state militias offering their quick hit-and-run skills to the armies that use them.

Due to Marienburg's title of center of trade in the Empire, merchant ships require elite troops that can defend their goods on the seas. Heavily armed, and used to fighting on the seas, Westerlander marines can also be used to fight on land as well as at sea.

the Westerlands are a harsh, and barren lands unsuited for major farming or even logging. This forces the majority of the population to take to the seas, with these shipyards being the lifeblood of the Westerland, delivering foodstuffs and other materials not found in the Westerlands.

Thanks to Marienburg, trade flows to and through the city all across the Empire, but many greedily eye such treasures, wanting it all for themselves. With these Watchtowers, trade can be secured and protected.

Long ago, before Solland was destroyed by the hands of Greenskins, Solland was a well respected Elector-County, rich and powerful due to their trade from the south. But, with Solland destroyed, many of the displaced nobles donned black armor and began forming into what they called Black Rider companies. They assist Sollanders whenever they can, and are a feared fighting force in the field.

Much like Black Rider companies, Auffrischer companies are Sollanders whom have taken up sword, pike, and shield in an effort to restore their lost glory. Due to this, they are not easily broken, and will fight like a wounded animal to protect their home and hearth.

In the days of old, Solland was a hub of trade activity in the south of the Empire thanks to the trading destination of Nuln. The old trade roads still see use by merchants, but a presistant lord can invest in the roads to encourage merchants to travel the roads like in the days of old.

Averland has a proud martial history, being the descendents of the Brigundians, masters of chariot and cavalry warfare. While they may no longer use chariots, and the nobles may be the only ones that can afford to use the heavy weapons and armor, the free companies of Averland are nothing to bat the eye at, for they will hold their position, no matter what is thrown at them

Averland is a place of rolling hills and fertile grasslands for as far as the eye can see. Thanks to this, Averland has many farms and mansions spread out across it's lands, to which they use to feed themselves and the rest of the Empire.

Long ago, Averland was populated by the Brigundians, masters of cavalry warfare, providing Sigmar with his elite cavalry forces needed to unite the Empire and defend it. While the Brigundians are no more, their traditions remain a proud, dutifuly practiced tradition among the nobility of Averland, producing some of the finest horsemen in all of the Empire.

Stirland is a county deeply rooted in tradition and superstition, believing completely in the age old saying 'If it ain't broke, don't fix it'. This is mirrored in their free companies, who are stubborn attackers and defenders in any situation.

Death Watch is an unofficial order of undead hunters that scour the lands of Stirland hunting the evil things that lurk in the night. They are made up of mostly peasants, whom are given formal training and the equipment required to hunt such beasts.

Stirland is a poor and barbaric land, unsuitable for farming and trading. So instead, the peasantry take to hunting, and due to Stirland's proximity to Sylvania, these hunters are hardend souls used to seeing monstrous horrors that would make a normal man run for his life, some even actively hunt said beasts.

Talabecland is a realm that is swallowed whole by the Great Forest, the largest of five great forests in the Empire. Like all of the forests, it harbors untold amounts of bandits, Greenskins, Beastmen, and even sometimes Chaos warriors should an invasion fail. Due to this, Talabecland has formed an elite archer unit comprised of the local hunters, tasked with hunting and exterminating any dark threats that lurk in the shadows of the Great Forests of the Empire.

While the Empire continues to try and contain the vast forests that grow within it's borders, it is sometimes neglectful of it's roads that criss-cross the entirety of the Empire. Traveling the Empire in good times can take weeks, especially going through Woodland Roads. Due to the sheer amount of danger inhabiting these forests, stopping to rest in the middle of nowhever is impracticle, so the Elector-Counties-Talabecland especially- have established fortified coaching inns along the roads for merchants and travellers to rest in safety.

Thanks to Talabecland being almost completely consumed by the Great Forest, logging has become a norm in the Elector-County. While it provides money and supplies to the county, it isn't exactly a safe job, with bandits, Greenskins, and even Beastmen roaming the dark places of the forest, so each lumberjack is skilled in the use of a bow-and-arrow, and can be levied in times of war to support the militia of Talabecland.

Drakwald is a harsh, and unforgiving land, it's people tempered by the forest, and long remember their ancestors, the Thuringians. This life-style is reflected in it's Free Companies, hardy and unshakable. Drakwalder companies are mostly gunpowder and archer units, as the Drakwald forest engulfs all of the county of Drakwald.

The Ehrwürdige Krieger, or venerable warriors, are Drakwald's finest soldiers. Having served in other Free companies for years, and returned to Drakwald to etch a life out of it's dark forests, these warriors are as unshakable as the mountains, and inspire others to follow in their footsteps.

The Drakwald is, for the most part, an isolated province, cut off from much of the rest of the empire, thanks to it's namesake forest. Due to this, many of the traditions of old still go on in the county, with the militias forming professional Heerbanns instead of militia units that the rest of the Empire uses.

The White Wolves of Middenland are an elite order, tasked with defending the Ar-Ulric and Middenland from harm. Each has sworn the oath of Ulric, and each have seen years of service in defense of the Middenland and the Ar-Ulric, making them a formidable force on the field of battle.

Like most of the northern Imperial counties, the Middenland has a long and proud martial tradition. Middenlander Greatswords are the finest soldiers of Middenland, and they would tell you they are the best in all of the Empire, and can back it up with their ferocity and will on the battlefield.

Thanks to Middenland's close proximity to the Drakwald, the Great Forest, and the Shadow forest, logging has become a norm in the Elector-County. While it provides money and supplies to the county, it isn't exactly a safe job, with bandits, Greenskins, and even Beastmen roaming the dark places of the forest, so each lumberjack is skilled in the use of a bow-and-arrow, and can be levied in times of war to support the militia of Middenladnd.

The Nordland, much like all counties in the north of the Empire, is a hard land, with the only constants being strife and death. While it does not have to bear the brunt of Chaos incursions, it is constantly pillaged and raided by the Norscans. But not all of them leave, as some settle down in the Nordland, bringing with them their belongings and traditions, of which the Nordland has adopted in the form of it's Warbands and Beserkers. High on some fort of shrooms and bloodlust, Beserkers throw themselves willingly into the frey with little regard for safety, carving bloody swaths into enemy formations.

Nordland is under constant threat from the Norscans to the north, raiding and pillaging villages and merchants in it's lands. Born out of desperation, the Nordland has established coastal guards to intercept the raiders before they land on it's shores, hoping to provide even a momentary respite from the constant raids from the north.

The Nordland, while sparsly populated, is home to not only Imperials, but Norscans as well that have been permitted to settle in the county. Due to this mix of cultures, Nordland does not field 'militias' but instead raises warbands, semi-professional soldiers that serve terms. Undisciple and barbaric, these soldiers are much more aggressive than their southern counterparts, but can be relied upon to hold a line or crush the enemy lines.

The reknown Hochland Long rifle companies are trained here, providing the state militia and Imperial armies with invaluable accurate, long range support. Crack shots, these sharpshooters can harass blocks of units just as well as harassing officers cores.

Not to be confused with Leon Todmeister's Fantabulously Far reaching Harquebus of Unforeseeable and Unperceived Bereavement, these hunters are armed with Hochland long rifles, which are handguns instead of fixed rifles. Much like the fixed rifles however, the handguns have superb accuracy and can fire at longer ranges than most standard Imperial handguns, making them excellent supporting units.

While not nearly as large as the Grey and Black mountains in the south that border the Wissenland, the Middle mountains are still rich with minerals, and better yet, are not filled with Dwarf Karaks, meaning the mineral rights do not have to be shared, and allow for more minerals to be extracted from the mountains.

The Desperate Sons are Sylvania's 'free companies'. With Sylvania being a poor and backward county, these free companies are truly a desperate lot, more often not even being able to afford the proper uniform, let alone weapons. But what they don't have in weapons and armor, they make up for in spirit, for they have lived all their lives in the cursed lands of Sylvania, they have nothing to fear.

Much like anything in Sylvania, the Forlorn Hope companies are depressing sights to behold. While they can actually afford weapons and armor, most shun the use of armor, for many within the Hopes' ranks are either criminals, or peasants that have lost their homes or families, and thus have nothing left to live for.

In stark contrast to the peasantry of Sylvania, the nobility are well-off and well groomed, living in impressive castles and living in luxury. However, much like anything in Sylvania, the nobles are expert fighters, sallying out in groups to cleanse their lands of mutants, heretics, and sometimes undead.

Ostermark is the northern most county in the Empire, sitting above Sylvania and to the east of Ostland and Hochland. Due to this, the Ostermark is normally the first to be assailed by marauding Chaos warhosts, and has developed an obsession with death. These horsemen are the embodiment of that obession.

The long history of the Ostermark and the countless invasions from the north it has endured has lead to the development of military tactics that counter the horse-based armies of the Chaos wastes. Pike-and-Shot regiments combine the firepower of gunpowder units with the staying power and protection of Pike units, making them difficult to overcome from the primarly melee cavalry based armies of the Chaos wastes.

After every chaos incursion, there are normally bands of northlanders that pillage and marauder Ostermark's countrysides, causing havoc and being a pain to any noble of the realm. Outriders are the answer to this. Fast, Hard hitting cavalry units that hunt down and destroy any warbands left behind from the incursion.

Ostland has a higher precentage of Ogres living in it's lands than other counties in the empire, many of which are marked as citizens of Ostland. In times of war, Ostland will commonly raise Ogre regiments alongside it's state troops to assist.
The Stur Guard are the Ostland's elite infantry forces. Stubborn as a bull, these warriors do no back down from a fight, and have long held many a Chaos incursion at bay in their homelands.

Due to Ostland being on the road to the Imperial capital, it's people must ever be vigilant against the dark incursions from the north, and have thus erected watchtowers along it's northern borders so that it may be warned ahead of time if such an invasion should accure.

While technically not having an Elector-County of their own, the Neueslanders are a proud people, a melting-pot of Imperial cultures that have fused together. Incorprating many different military traditions, Neueslander armies are powerful and flexiable threats to any would be invaders.
The 'Neue' towns are impressive centers of trade in their own right, encompassing large amounts of different cultures and faiths, these towns are rich and power.

Rough Riders are semi-professional cavalry units that patrol the borders of Neueslander lands for Bandits, Greenskins, and Beastmen. Due to the large amount of Neueslanders in the Border Princedoms, they commonly fight Greenskins, and have become experts at killing said Greenskins.

The Imperials of the Southlands are an interesting mix of Westerland and Medean cultures, having adopted the wares and cuisines of the Medeans, while keeping their Imperial roots. This means that the Sudenburgers are masters of bureaucracy, and have a certain regalness that is present even in their peasants.

Unlike the Imperial free companies of the homeland, Sudenland free companies are actually professional soldiers that are given terms, and live near a ruler's palace. They are better trained and equipped than the stock Imperial companies, and are the mainstay of any Sudenburger army.

Thanks to this holding's focus, it is providing Light Infantry regiments for our armies.

Thanks to this holding's focus, it is providing Gunner regiments for our armies.
This castle has set it's focus to fielding Artillery regiments.
Thanks to this holding's focus, it is providing Artillery regiments for our armies.
This castle has set it's focus to fielding War Elephant regiments.
Thanks to this holding's focus, it is providing War Elephant regiments for our armies.

The house of Knowledge is the center of learning for the palaces of the Sudenburgers, housing hundreds, sometimes thousands of different books, with topics ranging from science to mathematics, and even local epics wrote down onto paper.

In the Southlands and Araby, there are countless different exotic fruits that remain untapped by the local population. We can 'persuade' the locals to allow us to harvest the fruits and then sell them through out realm and to others for expensive prices to fill our coffers.

The Engineer Academy is much like the merchantile and military academies found in Imperial castles, except that instead of noble sons, it is the rich merchant sons that attend. The academicians are some of the brightest architects and engineers of the Empire, and thus help shore up the cities' walls and provide some artillery for the defenses.
The neighbouring stanitsas hold ancient traditions of Ropsmann tribes and fight on the ground as a tribal unit.
The neighbouring stanitsas hold the new traditions of the Kislevites, fighting in heavier armor and riding great bears into battle.
Streltsi Polks are raised here, armed with great axes and black powder weapons.
Ungol Polks are trained here, fighting in the ancient traditions of the Ungol tribes.
Here Ropsmann cavalry units are trained and raised, fighting in the ancient traditions of the original inhabitants of Kislev.
Ropsmann Polks are trained here, fighting in the ancient traditions of the Ropsmann tribes.
Here the mighty and famed bear cavalry units are trained. Unique and ferocious, just like their riders.
Kislevite Polks are trained here, ready to die in the defense of their home and motherland, Kislev.
The famous and deadly war bears are trained and raised here. Only a fool would stay and fight against them.

The Asrai, also known as the Wood Elves, are the descendents of High Elven colonists that recognized that the great forest that they lived in was alive. The Asrai ferociously defend the forest from invaders, and the forest repays them via their spellsingers shaping the forest to suit the needs of the Asrai.
The Woodland Moot is the military center of the Asrai forces, high up in the forest canopy, these fortresses house most of the Asrai's soldiers and weapons for when Kurnous calls for the Wild Hunt.
The Gladeguard are the mainstay of the Asrai warhosts. Light footed, and excellent archers, the Gladeguard are formidable warriors that can make short work of any invading army.

The Deepwood Scouts are the elite archer forces of the Asrai. Tasked with patrolling the dark, dangerous places of the Deepwood, these warriors are an excellent addition to a warhost, easily able to whittle down enemy forces via ambush tactics.

Deep in the forests of the Athel-Loren lie many ancient glades, formed centuries before the High Elves of Ulthuan arrived in the forest. These glades are highly sacred to the Asrai, and each is jealously guarded by their protectors, for each is a conduit for the forest itself.

Every Asrai city has a specific quarter dedicated to the forest spirits of Athel-Loren. From these quarters, the Treekin and Treemen are kept. Treekin, and Treemen, are long dead Asrai that have willingly taken control of a form gifted to them from the forest itself. When the Wild Hunt is called, these spirits are roused to the hunt, and are fightening foes to face on the battlefield.

The great temples of the Asrai are heavily defended places, in part thanks to the spellsingers, whom place wards upon the very bark that make up the building materials of the temple structures that defend these sacred lands.

Asrai Temples do not have walls that surround their holy places. Instead, various aspects are placed around the parameter of the temple, the most common being those of seclusion, which maskes the temple grounds from outsiders, making it difficult to find the temple in the dark forests of Athel-Loren.

At the heart of every Asrai temple lies an Elder Grove, an ancient gathering place that is as old as Athel-Loren itself. A conduit for the forest itself, these places are considered sacred by the Asrai, and are defended jealously by the spellsingers, whom can commune with the great forest.

Each temple holds host to a large contigent of warriors and bodyguards whos purpose most of the time is the defense of the temple grounds. But in times of war or during a Wild Hunt, these warriors are fielded into warhosts and help bolster the Gladeguard's numbers.

While Athel-Loren is completely forested, the various temples spread around the great forest have vast clearings designed to house and support cavalry regiments for the Asrai. Swift and deadly riders, they form the avante-guarde of any warhost, harassing and chasing down invaders that dare to stand against them.

Due to how highly regarded the temples of Athel-Loren are, many Asrai travel and stay at the temples, for one reason or another. Most stay for spirtual reasons, for the temple grounds are elder, and are said to be conduits for the forest itself, so that it may more easily communicate with those that live in its borders.

The spellsingers are the magic users of the Asrai, and also give voice to the great forest itself. They are able to speak to the forest, and can shape it's woods to suit the needs of the Asrai, whether it be for housing, or weapons and armor, or even to rouse the forest spirits to war.

Every temple is the center conduit for the forest of Athel-Loren, where it's will is more easy to manifest and interpret. Each temple is precious, and there are very few in the forest itself, so each is heavily guarded by an elite contigent of Wildwood and Deepwood scouts, which can serve as an elite core during the hunt or war-times.

The Fimir are an ancient race of Cyclops-like, half-daemonic monsters that inhabit the marshes and bogs of the old world. Long ago, these twisted and evil creatures were the chosen servants of the Dark Gods, but when the first of Mankind arrived, the Fimir lost the favor of their patrons, and their dark empire fell. Now, most live in Ruined, Desolate fortresses and castles deep in the bogs and marshes of the old world.
The Shearl are the lowest in the Fimir caste system, being the 'drones' of the race. They are a stupid, slow-witted bunch, and are mostly used as chaff for the nobles and warriors.

The Fimm are the second highest class in the Fimir caste system, being the warriors and nobles of the race. While they are about as intelligent as an Ork, they have the same brutish strength and behaviour, easily overpowering a man.

The Dirach are the third highest class of the Fimir caste system, being the wizards and priests of the race. Much like the Meargh, they are highly intelligent, and the Dirach are capable of controlling and binding Daemons to their services, such as Nuckelavees. While not as powerful as a trained Human wizard, Dirach are still very deadly, and can demolish scores of soldiers in seconds.

While the Shearl do not wear armor into battle, the Fimm, Dirach, and Meargh do wear rudimenary armor and have some quality weapons to use, but most of these arms and wears come from the long abandon stocks of their home, left when the previous inhabitants either died or abandon the fortress.

While some Halflings are known to travel with companies of reknown, most choose to live in the Mootland, the homeland of the Halflings. It is a fertile place, which is technically part of the Elector-County of Averland.

While many Halflings prefer to fight with slings, slingshots, and bows, some will take to wielding spears and long-spears, and can be used to great defensive effect if positioned and supplied correctly.

A common misconception about Halflings is that they are not fighters. While they often are not, when defending home and hearth they become incredibly brave and stubborn, and the elder will send detatchments of scouts and foragers to the Imperial armies, as Halflings are excellent at finding food.

Due to some service to the Empire(such as not going on strike for longer than a week) the Elector-Count has decided to graciously grant the Halflings the schematics to a failed version of the Steam tank, which was built too small for any Human to fit into. Turns out that it is the perfect size for a Halfling. With some proper modifications, we could use this mighty machine in our army!

Ogres love one thing, eating, just about as much as Halflings do, and thanks to this shared interest, many Ogres migrate to the Moot and settle there permanently, providing the villages and towns with excellent heavy support should they come under attack.

The Hot-Pie Catapult is an intersting Halfling invention, made out of desperation by a Halfling cook when he came under attack by a Goblin force. He would eventually win the battle, in thanks to his makeshift artillery units that fired incredibly hot pies at the goblins, which proved to be surprisingly effective against them. Ever since the battle, the temples and shrines to Esmeralda always have a small number of these catapults, in case they come under attack.

Skeggi is a Norscan colony in the New World near Hexoatl. It isn't very rich or prosperous, and the constant threat of Lizardmen and jungle horrors loom over the castle, but this has proven to be an advantage. All sorts of adventurers, explorers, treasure hunters, and mad-men alike come and make port at Skeggi, bolstering its numbers and providing a source of manpower to keep the jungle and its inhabitiants at bay.

The Grand Colony of El Cadavo, is Estalia's gem in the New World, bordered by Skeggi to the north, pirates to the south, and of course the Lizardmen everywhere else. Due to the constant threat, protection is a major concern for the city, and as such they have spared no expense in employing the famed Tercio formations of Estalia to the New World. But the city is not all war, as it also sits in a strategic trade position, sending goods across the ocean home to Estalia.

Vampire's Cove, built upon the old ruins of Huatl, is a hub for pirate activity in central Lustria. Huatl was but a ruin of the Lizardmen, but once Luther Harkon and his undead pirate crew arrived, they conquered the stretch of Lustrian coastline now known as the Vampire coast. It is now as rich or powerful as any other coastal settlement, in no small thanks to being ruled by an immortal vampire.

Al-Aliman is an Arabyan Colony founded by Atruhayid corsairs, fierce mariners who still follow the old ways of Araby. Another recent colony with more spirit and ambition than solid power or wealth, it serves as a central hub of Old Worlder activity in southern Lustria. With spices and other exotic wares flowing through, and more and more adventurers and misfits arriving in search of adventure, the future of Al-Aliman seems promising and more importantly, profitable. It also fields famed Arabyan stallions, some of the finest horses in Lustria, not that there are many others to compete against!

Qu'ittax is the largest Miyan-inhabited ruin in Lustria, and used to be an important city-temple of the Lizardmen. A great pit full of teeth and jagged rocks lies at it's center, where the Miyan perform bloody rituals to honour their ravenous god, Kukaili.

Ganaina is the largest Amazon stronghold in Lustria, and the most important religious center as well. The core of this settlement is a collection of ancient pyramids and towers built by the Old Ones. This complex extends deep into the earth, creating a labyrinth of linked underground vaults full of the wonders left by their creators. The two largest pyramids looming over the settlement are the Queen's Palace and the Temple of Rigg. The Temple of Rigg is the heart of the Amazon faith, and the center of their teaching and instruction.

Miyan blowdart warriors are mustered here. Blowdarts are simple tools, but these barbaric halflings have been able to perfect its uses into an art-form, with weekly competitions, with the winner usually getting to eat a prisoner after all is said and done. They wear mostly padded armor, but also wear striking masks to frighten their enemies and bring them luck on the battlefield. Their darts are tipped with poison from the most poisonous plants and frogs in the area, and it is considered a great honor to not only catch the frogs and tip darts in their poison, but also eat them...

The great Ziggurat-factory of Mazur, unbeknownst to most, has been for centuries one of the few wards against the Jade Vampires exterting their influence across the Old World. The Dawi Zharr of Mazur work their slaves to death to produce more warmachines and fortifications to defend their holdings in the Dragon Isles against the insidious threat of the Cathayan vampires.

When the Jade first arrived on the Dragon Isles, they used their gaze to brainwash almost all of the local Lizardmen, turning them into obedient slaves. Yet, the Old Ones provided for their children and one of their Spawning Pools gave birth to a wise and powerful Skink Priest who resisted the Jade and freed some of their siblings. Mabuya is the last independent outpost of the Lost Lizardmen, desperately trying to survive the vampiric invasion from the east.
